abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement action plan describes
            the procedure for acquiring land for public use and
            compensation of populations impacted by the Second Social
            Action Project for Burundi, by mobilizing and strengthening
            community capacity through subprojects that repair and build
            small-scale community infrastructure. The project targets
            the communes with the poorest and most vulnerable
            populations, principally focusing on communes attempting to
            reintegrate relatively high numbers of refugees and
            internally displaced persons. In general the legislative
            framework provides for monetary compensation. The land to be
            expropriated is mainly uninhabited so that compensation
            needed will be minimal and determined by experts.
            Beneficiaries of cultivated land will determine its use by
            community consensus. During the outbreak of civil war,
            displaced populations temporarily occupied community
            infrastructures; if similar circumstances arise, the state
            and nongovernmental organizations are sufficiently prepared
            to respond to the situation. Land owners who have their
            water supply diverted will either be compensated monetarily
            or with land exchanged at a cost that covers the cost of
            reinstallation. Where major technical constraints would
            affect the surrounding community, their consensus will be
            required. Generally, in order to be compensated, project
            affected persons do not have to be holders of title. All
            persons who have a right of title because of customary law,
            or all persons conducting an activity tied to the
            expropriated land, have a right to compensation at the same
            level as those whom the State licensed to carry out that
            activity. The plan also provides for conflict management in
            the case of conflicts over the choice of sites and over expropriation.
